node.title: Adding conda and homebrew PATH to .bash profile.
node.bodyText: Hi, I had a similar problem as discussed in #24342. Although I fixed the error temporarily, I’m wondering how to fix it permanently by adding the PATH to my .bash profile. I can’t figure out where my .bash profile is located. Could someone please direct me? Thanks.

Depends on the system... Homebrew is usually a Macintosh user thing, so what you want to change might actually be your ZSH profile. In either case, if you are using Bash these files (and others) are directly located in your $HOME directory:
(some files may not exist)
~/.bashrc         # BASH 
~/.bash_profile   # BASH
~/.profile        # BASH I've seen Homebrew stick things here sometimes
~/.zshrc          # Zsh
Why so many BASH profiles? I think the man page sums it up best (scroll down to "INVOCATION").
Hopefully you are using Zsh. As its a bit less complicated. You can verify what shell your terminal defaults to by running the following command (my machine spits back -zsh):
❯ echo $0
-zsh
If you are using a GUI file manager, these files (and others which begin with a period) are hidden. They are also likely hidden without using additional listing arguments to ls. Example:
❯ mkdir ~/temp; cd ~/temp
❯ touch .hidden
❯ ls

❯ ls -a
.       ..      .hidden
thanks, @milljm!

node.title: Multiapp transfer
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I have a master which has two multi-apps (sub1 and sub2) solving time-dependent problems.
Say you u = 0 in the master, which is passed to sub1, which returns u_new to the mater.
Now, when I pass u from the mater to sub2, it still pass u = 0 (and not u_new). Only in the
next time, does the master pass u_new to the sub app. So my simulation is lagging behind
by one time step.
How can I fix this?
Thank you.
Karthik.

Hello
you could execute the multiapp on time step end to begin with. This will make sure the field sent to the multiapp is updated.
If you want to synchronize the two applications more, you can turn on fixed point iterations between the parent and child apps in the executioner block.
You may want to turn verbose_multiapps=true in the executioner block for now to set this up
Guillaume

Hi @GiudGiud
Thank you for your response.
I have three multi-apps,
master->app1_sub1
master->app2_sub1->app2_sub2->app2_sub3
master->app3_sub1
Say,
app1_sub1 solves Equation 1. It needs u3, u2 and provides u1.
app2_sub1(->sub2->sub3) solves Equation 2. It needs u1 and provides u2.
app3_sub1 solves Equation 3. It needs u1, u2 and provides u3.
There are initial conditions for u3 and u1. The master just collects the variables and transfers all the variables to the respective multi-apps.
Q1) I am not sure, how to order the apps, probably I can execute app1_sub1 on timestep_begin and app2_sub1 on timestep_end. What do I execute app3_sub1 on?
Q2) Perhaps Picard (fixed-point) iteration, as you suggested is the way to go to ensure proper coupling between the variables before moving to the next time step. I am not sure how to set up the convergence criteria. All three variables need to be converged before moving to the next time step. What goes into the executioner block? I am new to using Picard iteration.
Thank you,
Karthik.

Q1)
I would execute app3 on timestep end. There's no way to have u1 updated and at the same time provide an updated u3 to app1
And that's where fixed point iterations (Picard) come in.
btw if the main app does not provide any field of interest to the sub apps you can execute every subapp on timestep end.
Q2)
There are quite a few parameters to the Picard iterations for multiapps.
You can see all these parameters, and the several ways to set the convergence criterion (either main app nonlienar residual or a custom postprocessor) in the Executioner parameters under Fixed Point Iterations parameters
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/executioners/Steady.html

@GiudGiud Thank you for your response.
The main app only gathers the variables (u1, u2, u3) from the sub-app and does not solve.
[Problem]
  type = FEProblem
  solve = false
[]

So only auxiliary variables exist in the main app. However, I would like to set the Picard convergence criterion for u1, u2 and u3 in the main app. Does it make sense to set something like the below in the executioner block of the main app?
  picard_max_its = 10
  picard_rel_tol = 1e-6
  picard_abs_tol = 1e-10

Kind regards,
Karthi

no this wont work.
You ll want to use the custom_pp convergence option.
You can create a "change in a variable" postprocessor using the existing ones

@GiudGiud,
I know how to create a post-processor, which I understand returns a single scalar quantity.
Q1) What is the convergence criterion on i.e like an l2 error norm pp of an aux variable?
Q2) Will the above pp be checked against the previous iteration for convergence?
Q3) Sorry, I am not following what you mean by "change in a variable" pp. Are we changing the aux variable to a regular variable using pp?
Best,
Karthi

use this PP
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/postprocessors/ChangeOverTimestepPostprocessor.html
Q1) Yes you should use something like that. Or L1 norm maybe
Q2) You can work to make that happen. Please refer to the fixed point iteration documentation from the Executioner
Q3) No, PPs do not convert from regular to aux or aux to regular.

@GiudGiud
Thank you. I almost understand how to get it to work.
Looks like the ChangeOverTimeStepPostprocessor convergence criterion is something like |y^n+1| -  |y^n| provided a specific norm.
Where y is the field variable and n is the Picard iteration number.
However shouldn't the convergence be on |y^n+1 -  y^n| going to zero instead?
I think this can't be accomplished via ChangeOverTimePostprocessor as it only takes the difference between scalar qualities and not field variables.

oh ok might be another postprocessor.
You could compute the residuals in the apps with
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/auxkernels/DebugResidualAux.html
then transfer the residuals from the apps to main app then use this to compare them to 0
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/postprocessors/ElementL2FunctorError.html

@GiudGiud
Alternatively,  instead of doing the following
app1_sub1 solves Equation 1. It needs u3, u2 and provides u1.
app2_sub1(->sub2->sub3) solves Equation 2. It needs u1 and provides u2.
app3_sub1 solves Equation 3. It needs u1, u2 and provides u3.
I could do
Master solves u3, provided u1,u2
(but u3 will be zero for the first iteration as u1=u2=0 but Picard iteration will eventually make u3 to converge)
app1_sub1 solves Equation 1. It needs u3, u2 and provides u1.
app2_sub1(->sub2->sub3) solves Equation 2. It needs u1 and provides u2.
Then I set the Picard convergence criterion directly on u3, which would be a non-linear variable not make use of ChangeOverTimeStepPostprocessor?
that works too

node.title: Custom PenaltyEqualValueConstraint with prescribed displacement jump
node.bodyText:
Hi all, this is a follow-up discussion after #24894. I try to setup a simple dynamic problem to test the correctness of this custom constraint, but it seems like it doesn't solve anything with the nonzero prescribed slip, I wonder if there is something wrong in the setup, thanks!
This is the input file:
[Mesh]
    [./msh]
        type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
        dim = 2
        nx = 10
        ny = 10
        xmin = -500
        xmax = 500
        ymin = -500
        ymax = 500
    []
    [./new_block]
        type = ParsedSubdomainMeshGenerator
        input = msh
        combinatorial_geometry = 'y<0'
        block_id = 1
    []
    [./split]
        type = BreakMeshByBlockGenerator
        input = new_block
        split_interface = true
        add_interface_on_two_sides = true
    []
[]

[GlobalParams]
    ##primary variable
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
[]

[Variables]
    [./disp_x]
        order = FIRST
        family = LAGRANGE
    [../]
    [./disp_y]
        order = FIRST
        family = LAGRANGE
    [../]
[]

[AuxVariables]
    [./accel_x]
        order = FIRST
        family = LAGRANGE
    [../]
    [./vel_x]
        order = FIRST
        family = LAGRANGE
    [../]
    [./accel_y]
        order = FIRST
        family = LAGRANGE
    [../]
    [./vel_y]
        order = FIRST
        family = LAGRANGE
    [../]
    [./slip_iter]
        order = CONSTANT
        family = MONOMIAL
    []
    [./slip_zero]
        order = CONSTANT
        family = MONOMIAL
    []
[]

[AuxKernels]
    [./accel_x] 
        type = NewmarkAccelAux
        variable = accel_x
        displacement = disp_x
        velocity = vel_x
        beta = 0.25
        execute_on = TIMESTEP_END
    [../]
    [./vel_x] 
        type = NewmarkVelAux
        variable = vel_x
        acceleration = accel_x
        gamma = 0.5
        execute_on = TIMESTEP_END
    [../]
    [./accel_y]
        type = NewmarkAccelAux
        variable = accel_y
        displacement = disp_y
        velocity = vel_y
        beta = 0.25
        execute_on = TIMESTEP_END
    [../]
    [./vel_y]
        type = NewmarkVelAux
        variable = vel_y
        acceleration = accel_y
        gamma = 0.5
        execute_on = TIMESTEP_END
    [../]
    [./const_val]
        type = ConstantAux
        value = 1
        variable = slip_iter
        execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_BEGIN'
        boundary = 'Block0_Block1'
    []
[]

[Modules]
    [./TensorMechanics]
      [./Master]
        [./all]
          strain = SMALL
          displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
          planar_formulation = PLANE_STRAIN
        [../]
      [../]
    [../]
[]

[Kernels]
    [./inertia_x]
        type = InertialForce
        use_displaced_mesh = false
        variable = disp_x
        velocity = vel_x
        acceleration = accel_x
        beta = 0.25
        gamma = 0.5
    []
    [./inertia_y]
        type = InertialForce
        use_displaced_mesh = false
        variable = disp_y
        velocity = vel_y
        acceleration = accel_y
        beta = 0.25
        gamma = 0.5
    []
[]

[Constraints]
    [slip_constraint_x]
        type = PenaltySlipConstraint
        primary_boundary = 'Block0_Block1'
        secondary_boundary = 'Block1_Block0'
        primary_subdomain = 'Block0'
        secondary_subdomain = 'Block1'
        slip_iter = slip_iter
        penalty_value = 1e6
        primary_variable = disp_x
        secondary_variable = disp_x
    []
    [slip_constraint_y]
        type = PenaltySlipConstraint
        primary_boundary = 'Block0_Block1'
        secondary_boundary = 'Block1_Block0'
        primary_subdomain = 'Block0'
        secondary_subdomain = 'Block1'
        slip_iter = slip_zero
        penalty_value = 1e6
        primary_variable = disp_y
        secondary_variable = disp_y
    []
[]

[Executioner]
    type = Transient
    solve_type = 'NEWTON'
    start_time = 0
    num_steps = 1
    l_tol = 1e-6
    nl_rel_tol = 1e-6
    nl_max_its = 100
    nl_abs_tol = 1e-10
    dt = 0.005
    timestep_tolerance = 1e-6
    petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -ksp_gmres_restart'
    petsc_options_value = 'lu       101'
    automatic_scaling = true
    line_search = 'none'
[]

[Preconditioning]
    [smp]
      type = SMP
      full = true
    []
[]

[Materials]
    [elasticity]
        type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
        lambda = 1
        shear_modulus = 1
        use_displaced_mesh = false
    []
    [stress]
        type = ComputeLinearElasticStress
    []
    [density]
        type = GenericConstantMaterial
        prop_names = density
        prop_values = 1
    []
[]

[Outputs]
    exodus = true
    interval = 1
[]

This is the custom constraint file:
//* This file is part of the MOOSE framework
//* https://www.mooseframework.org
//*
//* All rights reserved, see COPYRIGHT for full restrictions
//* https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/master/COPYRIGHT
//*
//* Licensed under LGPL 2.1, please see LICENSE for details
//* https://www.gnu.org/licenses/lgpl-2.1.html

#pragma once

#include "MortarConstraint.h"
#include "ADMortarConstraint.h"

// Forward declaration
template <bool is_ad>
using MortarConstraintTempl =
    typename std::conditional<is_ad, ADMortarConstraint, MortarConstraint>::type;

/**
 * Constrain the value of a variable to be the same on both sides of an
 * interface using a generalized force stemming from a penalty-based enforcement.
 */
template <bool is_ad>
class PenaltySlipConstraintTempl : public MortarConstraintTempl<is_ad>
{
public:
  static InputParameters validParams();

  PenaltySlipConstraintTempl(const InputParameters & parameters);

protected:
  GenericReal<is_ad> computeQpResidual(Moose::MortarType mortar_type) final;
  GenericReal<is_ad> computeQpJacobian(Moose::ConstraintJacobianType jacobian_type,
                                       unsigned int jvar);

  /// Penalty value used to enforce the constraint
  const Real _penalty_value;
  const VariableValue _slip_iter;

  using MortarConstraintTempl<is_ad>::_u_primary;
  using MortarConstraintTempl<is_ad>::_u_secondary;
  using MortarConstraintTempl<is_ad>::_test_primary;
  using MortarConstraintTempl<is_ad>::_test_secondary;
  using MortarConstraintTempl<is_ad>::_qp;
  using MortarConstraintTempl<is_ad>::_i;
  using MortarConstraintTempl<is_ad>::_j;
  using MortarConstraintTempl<is_ad>::coupledValue;
};

typedef PenaltySlipConstraintTempl<false> PenaltySlipConstraint;
typedef PenaltySlipConstraintTempl<true> ADPenaltySlipConstraint;

#include "PenaltySlipConstraint.h"
#include "MortarConstraintBase.h"

registerMooseObject("farms_rsfApp", PenaltySlipConstraint);
registerMooseObject("farms_rsfApp", ADPenaltySlipConstraint);

template <bool is_ad>
InputParameters
PenaltySlipConstraintTempl<is_ad>::validParams()
{
  InputParameters params = MortarConstraintTempl<is_ad>::validParams();
  params.addClassDescription(
      "PenaltySlipConstraint enforces solution continuity between secondary and "
      "primary sides of a mortar interface using a penalty approach (no Lagrange multipliers "
      "needed)");
  params.addRequiredRangeCheckedParam<Real>(
      "penalty_value",
      "penalty_value>0",
      "Penalty value used to impose a generalized force capturing the mortar constraint equation");
  params.addRequiredCoupledVar("slip_iter","slip value at current iteration");
  return params;
}

template <bool is_ad>
PenaltySlipConstraintTempl<is_ad>::PenaltySlipConstraintTempl(
    const InputParameters & parameters)
  : MortarConstraintTempl<is_ad>(parameters),
    _penalty_value(this->template getParam<Real>("penalty_value")),
    _slip_iter(coupledValue("slip_iter"))
{
}

template <bool is_ad>
GenericReal<is_ad>
PenaltySlipConstraintTempl<is_ad>::computeQpResidual(Moose::MortarType mortar_type)
{

  switch (mortar_type)
  {
    case Moose::MortarType::Secondary:
    {
      auto residual =
          -(_u_primary[_qp] - _u_secondary[_qp] - _slip_iter[_qp]) * _penalty_value * _test_secondary[_i][_qp];

      return residual;
    }

    case Moose::MortarType::Primary:
    {
      auto residual =
          (_u_primary[_qp] - _u_secondary[_qp] - _slip_iter[_qp]) * _penalty_value * _test_primary[_i][_qp];

      return residual;
    }

    default:
      return 0;
  }
}

template <>
ADReal
PenaltySlipConstraintTempl<true>::computeQpJacobian(
    Moose::ConstraintJacobianType /*jacobian_type*/, unsigned int /*jvar*/)
{
  mooseError("ADPenaltySlipConstraint does not implement manual Jacobian calculation.");
}

template <>
Real
PenaltySlipConstraintTempl<false>::computeQpJacobian(
    Moose::ConstraintJacobianType jacobian_type, unsigned int jvar)
{
  typedef Moose::ConstraintJacobianType JType;

  switch (jacobian_type)
  {
    case JType::SecondarySecondary:
      if (jvar == _secondary_var.number())
        return (*_phi)[_j][_qp] * _penalty_value * _test_secondary[_i][_qp];
      break;

    case JType::SecondaryPrimary:
      if (jvar == _primary_var.number())
        return -(*_phi)[_j][_qp] * _penalty_value * _test_secondary[_i][_qp];
      break;

    case JType::PrimarySecondary:
      if (jvar == _secondary_var.number())
        return -(*_phi)[_j][_qp] * _penalty_value * _test_primary[_i][_qp];
      break;

    case JType::PrimaryPrimary:
      if (jvar == _primary_var.number())
        return (*_phi)[_j][_qp] * _penalty_value * _test_primary[_i][_qp];
      break;

    default:
      return 0;
  }

  return 0;
}

template class PenaltySlipConstraintTempl<false>;
template class PenaltySlipConstraintTempl<true>;

_slip_iter(coupledValue("slip_iter"))

you should probably use the coupledGenericValue templated on is_ad here, for the future to make sure derivatives are not lost here (for now it's ok, slip_iter is an aux variable)
Does Debug/show_execution_order show this constraint is executed as expected?

It seems like the constraint is not called..
[DBG] Executing boundary restricted auxkernels on boundary elements on INITIAL

Time Step 0, time = 0

Time Step 1, time = 0.005, dt = 0.005
[DBG] Executing boundary restricted auxkernels on boundary elements on TIMESTEP_BEGIN
[DBG] Beginning elemental loop to compute Residual on LINEAR
[DBG] Execution order on each element:
[DBG] - kernels on element quadrature points
[DBG] - finite volume elemental kernels on element
[DBG] - integrated boundary conditions on element side quadrature points
[DBG] - DG kernels on element side quadrature points
[DBG] - interface kernels on element side quadrature points
[DBG] Ordering of Residual Objects on block  (0)
[DBG] Ordering of kernels:
[DBG] TM_all0 TM_all1 inertia_x inertia_y

Performing automatic scaling calculation

[DBG] Beginning elemental loop to compute Residual on LINEAR
[DBG] Ordering of Residual Objects on block  (0)
[DBG] Ordering of kernels:
[DBG] TM_all0 TM_all1 inertia_x inertia_y
 0 Nonlinear |R| = 0.000000e+00
 Solve Converged!
[DBG] Beginning nodal loop of nodal auxiliary kernels on TIMESTEP_END
[DBG] Ordering of the kernels on each block they are defined on:
[DBG] accel_x vel_x accel_y vel_y

ok you should check the sidesets then
I ll have to double check that Constraints are actually output by the Debug option. I could have forgotten them
@recuero Hi Antonio, we had a discussion before about this. Do you have any idea? Thanks a lot

It's unclear to me how you are generating your lower dimensional domains for your mortar/slip constraint --which you seem to need, e.g. Block0_Block1. Also, you'd need to block restrict your physics if you have mortar constraints in your system.

This BreakMeshByBlockGenerator will generate the sideset Block0_Block1 which Block0 is the primary surface and Block1 is the secondary surface, I have add_interface_on_two_sides = true which gives me Block1_Block0, I'm not sure whether this fits into the constraint framework or not

You can see if the lower dimensional domains get generated in the output, e.g. in Paraview. In that case, you'd need to block restrict your physics, e.g. your mechanics to not act on those lower-dimensional domains.

I checked the lower dimensional domain indeed there in Paraview. How to do "block restrict" to be more specific?
[Constraints]
    [slip_constraint_x]
        type = PenaltySlipConstraint
        primary_boundary = 'Block0_Block1'
        secondary_boundary = 'Block1_Block0'
        primary_subdomain = 'Block0'
        secondary_subdomain = 'Block1'
        slip_iter = slip_iter
        penalty_value = 1e6
        primary_variable = disp_x
        secondary_variable = disp_x
    []
    [slip_constraint_y]
        type = PenaltySlipConstraint
        primary_boundary = 'Block0_Block1'
        secondary_boundary = 'Block1_Block0'
        primary_subdomain = 'Block0'
        secondary_subdomain = 'Block1'
        slip_iter = slip_zero
        penalty_value = 1e6
        primary_variable = disp_y
        secondary_variable = disp_y
    []
[]

In:
[Modules]
    [./TensorMechanics]
      [./Master]
        [./all]
          strain = SMALL
          displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
          planar_formulation = PLANE_STRAIN
          block = 'Blocks_that_are_not_lower_dimensional_for_mortar'
        [../]
      [../]
    [../]
[]

And the same for other physics/kernels if you have them.

I meant that, in the line below, you should include the higher dimensional blocks. Not the lower-dimensional blocks that are generated to impose constraints with a mortar formulation. I.e. your blocks can be "1" and "2", in which case you would do blocks = '1 2'
    block = 'Blocks_that_are_not_lower_dimensional_for_mortar'

Thanks! I tried, but it doesn't work also..
[Mesh]
    [./msh]
        type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
        dim = 2
        nx = 10
        ny = 10
        xmin = -500
        xmax = 500
        ymin = -500
        ymax = 500
    []
    [./new_block]
        type = ParsedSubdomainMeshGenerator
        input = msh
        combinatorial_geometry = 'y<0'
        block_id = 1
    []
    [./split]
        type = BreakMeshByBlockGenerator
        input = new_block
        split_interface = true
        add_interface_on_two_sides = true
    []
[]

[GlobalParams]
    ##primary variable
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
[]

[Variables]
    [./disp_x]
        order = FIRST
        family = LAGRANGE
    [../]
    [./disp_y]
        order = FIRST
        family = LAGRANGE
    [../]
[]

[AuxVariables]
    [./accel_x]
        order = FIRST
        family = LAGRANGE
    [../]
    [./vel_x]
        order = FIRST
        family = LAGRANGE
    [../]
    [./accel_y]
        order = FIRST
        family = LAGRANGE
    [../]
    [./vel_y]
        order = FIRST
        family = LAGRANGE
    [../]
    [./slip_iter]
        order = CONSTANT
        family = MONOMIAL
    []
    [./slip_zero]
        order = CONSTANT
        family = MONOMIAL
    []
[]

[AuxKernels]
    [./accel_x] 
        type = NewmarkAccelAux
        variable = accel_x
        displacement = disp_x
        velocity = vel_x
        beta = 0.25
        execute_on = TIMESTEP_END

    [../]
    [./vel_x] 
        type = NewmarkVelAux

    [../]
    [./accel_y]
        type = NewmarkAccelAux

    [../]

[]

[Kernels]

[]

[Constraints]
    [slip_constraint_x]
        type = PenaltySlipConstraint
        primary_boundary = 'Block0_Block1'
        secondary_boundary = 'Block1_Block0'
        primary_subdomain = 'Block0'

[Executioner]
    type = Transient
    solve_type = 'NEWTON'

    petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -ksp_gmres_restart'
    petsc_options_value = 'lu       101'
    automatic_scaling = true
    line_search = 'none'
[]

[Preconditioning]
    [smp]
      type = SMP
      full = true
    []
[]

[Materials]
    [elasticity]
        type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
        lambda = 1
        shear_modulus = 1
        use_displaced_mesh = false
    []
    [stress]
        type = ComputeLinearElasticStress
    []
    [density]
        type = GenericConstantMaterial
        prop_names = density
        prop_values = 1
    []
[]

[Outputs]
    exodus = true
    interval = 1
[]

[Debug]
    show_execution_order = ALWAYS
[]

node.title: solving with other Numerical Methods (MOL)
node.bodyText:
Hi there,
While working on my thesis, I came across this amazing framework. I'm wondering if it's possible to solve PDE-type problems with other numerical solutions. As an MSc. student in Welding Engineering, I'm particularly interested in using this framework to solve problems related to SMAW moving heat sources and temperature fields. However, in order to meet the requirements of my thesis proposal, I need to use the Method of Lines approach instead. Can you tell me if this is possible with the framework?

Hello
I suspect the method of lines is similar to the method of characteristics (MOC) (but with the characteristic being a line).
If so, then it can be done using the ray tracing module. We have a neutron transport MOC solver, so it can be done, we just can't share it.
Guillaume

Dear Guillaume
i really appreciate your guide but as i have a limited time to do my work , i wonder that isn't there any written code in these method
that i learn and modified them to adjust my case
thank you.

There's a few examples in the module
We also have this example doing MPM
https://github.com/loganharbour/moose/tree/rt_mpm

node.title: Kernel selection for NS equation
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE experts:
When I try to combine the Navier-Stokes equation and the Allen-Cahn equation, there is a surface tension term(marked in equation 2) and I don't know how to choose a suitable kernel for this term.
Comparing the form of the Cahn-Hilliard equation, the surface tension term in equation 2 looks similar to equation 1. The functional derivative of concentration can be regarded as chemical potential, and the difference between Cahn Hilliard equation and the surface tension term is that the former is \nebla (\M*\nebla miu) while in equation 2 is \phi*\ nebla miu (although strictly speaking, only the functional derivative of energy with respect to concentration can be called chemical potential).
I wonder if I can still use the SplitCHParsed kernel (although )with some other kernels to solve this term or should I write a new one?
@dschwen any thoughts on this?
Does anybody have some ideas?

node.title: Convergence issue while solving phase-field fracture
node.bodyText:
Hello MOOSE Experts
I am trying to solve rate-independent phase-field fracture using the following example
crack2d_iso_wo_time.i
for CT specimen geometry, the material properties are taken from Miehe's paper.
However, I am getting the following error as soon as the damage evolves to value 1.
  Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_ITS iterations 10
  Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_ITS iterations 10
  Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_ITS iterations 10
  Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_ITS iterations 10
  Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_ITS iterations 10
  Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_ITS iterations 10
  Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_ITS iterations 10
  Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_ITS iterations 10
  Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_ITS iterations 10
  Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_ITS iterations 10
Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_MAX_IT iterations 10
 Solve Did NOT Converge!


Input file I used is as follows;
#This input does not add time derivative kernel for phase field equation
[Mesh]
  file = 'Miehe.inp'
[]

[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
[]

[Modules]
  [./TensorMechanics]
    [./Master]
      [./mech]
        add_variables = true
        strain = SMALL
        additional_generate_output = 'stress_yy'
        save_in = 'resid_x resid_y'
      [../]
    [../]
  [../]
[]

[Variables]
  [./c]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  [../]
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [./resid_x]
  [../]
  [./resid_y]
  [../]
[]

[Kernels]
  [./solid_x]
    type = PhaseFieldFractureMechanicsOffDiag
    variable = disp_x
    component = 0
    c = c
  [../]
  [./solid_y]
    type = PhaseFieldFractureMechanicsOffDiag
    variable = disp_y
    component = 1
    c = c
  [../]
  [./ACBulk]
    type = AllenCahn
    variable = c
    f_name = F
  [../]

  [./ACInterface]
    type = ACInterface
    variable = c
    kappa_name = kappa_op
  [../]
[]

[BCs]
  [./ydisp]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = NS4
    function = 't'
  [../]
    [./xdisp]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = NS4
    value = 0
  [../]
  [./yfix]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = NS3
    value = 0
  [../]
  [./xfix]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = NS3
    value = 0
  [../]
[]

[Materials]
  [./pfbulkmat]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'gc_prop l visco'
    prop_values = '2.7 0.015 3.0e-6'
  [../]
  [./define_mobility]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    material_property_names = 'gc_prop visco'
    f_name = L
    function = '1.0/(gc_prop * visco)'
  [../]
  [./define_kappa]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    material_property_names = 'gc_prop l'
    f_name = kappa_op
    function = 'gc_prop * l'
  [../]
  [./elasticity_tensor]
    type = ComputeElasticityTensor
    C_ijkl = '121.0e3 80.0e3'
    fill_method = symmetric_isotropic
  [../]
  [./elastic]
    type = ComputeLinearElasticPFFractureStress
    c = c
    E_name = 'elastic_energy'
    D_name = 'degradation'
    F_name = 'local_fracture_energy'
    decomposition_type = strain_spectral
  [../]
  [./degradation]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    f_name = degradation
    args = 'c'
    function = '(1.0-c)^2*(1.0 - eta) + eta'
    constant_names       = 'eta'
    constant_expressions = '0.0'
    derivative_order = 2
  [../]
  [./local_fracture_energy]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    f_name = local_fracture_energy
    args = 'c'
    material_property_names = 'gc_prop l'
    function = 'c^2 * gc_prop / 2 / l'
    derivative_order = 2
  [../]
  [./fracture_driving_energy]
    type = DerivativeSumMaterial
    args = c
    sum_materials = 'elastic_energy local_fracture_energy'
    derivative_order = 2
    f_name = F
  [../]
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [./resid_x]
    type = NodalSum
    variable = resid_x
    boundary = NS3
  [../]
  [./resid_y]
    type = NodalSum
    variable = resid_y
    boundary = NS3
  [../]
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [./smp]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  [../]
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient

  automatic_scaling = true
  compute_scaling_once=false
  solve_type = 'PJFNK'
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type -ksp_gmres_restart'
  petsc_options_value = 'hypre boomeramg 101'

  nl_rel_tol = 1e-3
  l_tol = 1e-3

  l_max_its = 10
  nl_max_its = 10

  dt = 1e-5
  dtmin = 1e-6
  num_steps = 3500
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  interval = 10
[]

For reference. I have also uploaded the distribution of the damage field at the time just before the system diverged.
Can you please let me know the procedure to resolve this instability issue?
I shall be very thankful.
Best
Avtar

Hello
Can you please give us the full output log?
l_max_its of 10 is not a lot, this is triggering Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_ITS iterations 10, which could be taking down the non linear solver (since linear iterates are not very converged)
Guillaume

Please find the attached file. I increased the linear solver iterations to 50. Still, it's getting crashed at approx the same load step.
output.zip

Dear @asingh-mit
Try to start from the setup of the example with the variational inequality solver, which is well converging:
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/modules/combined/test/tests/phase_field_fracture/crack2d_vi_solver.i
Other convergence issues can be due to the load applied to quickly or the values of "l" and "visco"
Make sure "l" is about 4 times your mesh size, at least
The only thing I can see in your input file is:
nl_rel_tol = 1e-3
l_tol = 1e-3
These are too high, just leave them as default.
Also increase a bit number of linear and non-linear iterations
as suggested by @GiudGiud
You can see other examples of similar converging simulations here:
https://github.com/ngrilli/c_pfor_am/tree/main/test/tests/CPDamage
Best Regards,
Nicolò

Please follow @ngrilli 's advice first. And if it unfortunately doesnt work, please reduce your mesh to 1000 dofs or less and run with -pc_type svd -pc_svd_monitor  on the command line. This will let us know if the system becomes singular right when you are getting convergence issues.

Add one more thing: If your linear solver fails, try to use a direct solver.
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type'
 petsc_options_value = 'lu'

Thank you very much for the suggestions. Let you know the results after the simulation.
Hey @ngrilli
As you suggested about the load applied, I completely agree.
So, I am wondering if there is any method to decrease it after certain load steps.
Let's say,
I want to apply displacement of 1.0e-5 for the first 500 and then 1.0e-6 for the rest of the simulation.
Best
Avtar
Take a look at TimeSteppers  https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Executioner/TimeStepper/index.html

Hello MOOSE Experts
I followed the suggestions given by @ngrilli and @jiangwen84. But the system is still diverging as soon as the damage value reaches 1. Next, as suggested by @GiudGiud, I will decrease the problem size and provide the output.
I just have one doubt. I need to incorporate anisotropy in the phase-field fracture and also the rate-independent. Is it possible to do that or do I need to write the kernel for the same?
Best
Avtar

Dear @asingh-mit
Please attach the new input file, otherwise it's difficult to say.
Are you setting any initial condition for the damage field? Or does it start from 0 everywhere?
My experience is that you need to initialise the phase field with a function exp(-y/l)
so mimicking the steady state solution, otherwise you get convergence problems at the very beginning.
If your initial phase field is zero, there should not be problems.
Yes, anisotropic phase field fracture, to see anisotropic crack propagation, is already available in MOOSE:
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/modules/combined/test/tests/phase_field_fracture/crack2d_aniso_cleavage_plane.i
no need to write any kernel.
There is one further 3D example here:
https://github.com/ngrilli/c_pfor_am/blob/main/test/tests/CPDamage/AnisoCleavage.i
I made this and I am sure this is converging well and show crack propagation.
The fracture surface is a constant vector defined by "cleavage_plane_normal"
Best Regards,
Nicolò

Hello @ngrilli @jiangwen84 @GiudGiud
Thank you very much for your help.  I successfully validated the uniaxial tension test problem given in Prof. Miehe's Paper titled "Thermodynamically consistent phase-field models of fracture: Variational principles and multi-field FE implementations".
I have tried many solvers and preconditioners settings. I can only be able to solve with the following solver settings:
  solve_type = NEWTON
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_package -snes_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu       superlu_dist                  vinewtonrsls'
  automatic_scaling = true

Other solvers like PJFNK diverge as soon as the damage value reaches 1 or load started to drop. I have attached the two figures. First with PJFNK solver and second with Newton solver.
Best
Avtar

vinewtonrsls should work with PJFNK too, but not sure why it fails to converge for this case.
Yes, we typically use direct solver for mechanics/fracture problems, at least for 2D and small 3D cases.

node.title: New Formulation Dynamics
node.bodyText:
Another issue I ran into with Dynamics that I wanted to make known. I have two input files below, for a dynamics, non-damped example. It's very possible I set up the new formulation incorrectly. I know the problem is not damped, but I don't see why the New formulation seems to become more and more compressed.

  
    
    

    dynamics.mov
    
  

  

  


In the video, the white block is the new formulation and blue block is the AD version.
The other objective rates are worse and make the block seem more and more compressed.

New Formulation with InterialForce
beta = 0.25
gamma = 0.5

[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
  large_kinematics = true
[]
[Mesh]
  [gen]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    xmax = 0.30
    ymax = 0.5
    nx = 15
    ny = 25
    elem_type = QUAD4
    boundary_name_prefix = flexible
  []
[]

[Modules/TensorMechanics/Master]
  [all]
    strain = FINITE
    new_system = true
    add_variables = true
    formulation = TOTAL
  []
[]

[Kernels]
    [inertia_x]
      type = InertialForce
      variable = disp_x
    []
    [inertia_y]
      type = InertialForce
      variable = disp_y
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [elastic_tensor]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = 1e+4
    poissons_ratio = 0.4
  []
  [stress]
    type = ComputeLagrangianLinearElasticStress
    objective_rate = truesdell
  []
  [density]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'density'
    prop_values = '1'
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [hold_x]
    type = ADDirichletBC
    boundary = 'flexible_bottom'
    variable = disp_x
    value = 0
  []
  [hold_y]
    type = ADDirichletBC
    boundary = 'flexible_bottom'
    variable = disp_y
    value = 0
  []

  [Pressure]
    [push]
      function = 200
      boundary = 'flexible_left '
      use_automatic_differentiation = true
      use_displaced_mesh = true
    []
  []
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  end_time = 0.5
  dt = 1e-2
  solve_type = 'NEWTON'
  petsc_options = '-snes_converged_reason -ksp_converged_reason '
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_type -pc_factor_shift_type -pc_factor_shift_amount'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu       superlu_dist                  NONZERO 1e-15'

  line_search = 'none'
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-10
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-10

  [TimeIntegrator]
    type = NewmarkBeta
    beta = ${beta}
    gamma = ${gamma}
  []
[]

[Outputs]
  [exo]
    type = Exodus
    execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_END'
  []
  file_base = "new"
  print_linear_residuals = false
[]

AD Mechanics Version with InertialForce
beta = 0.25
gamma = 0.5

[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
[]
[Mesh]
  [gen]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    xmax = 0.30
    ymax = 0.5
    nx = 15
    ny = 25
    elem_type = QUAD4
    boundary_name_prefix = flexible
  []
[]

[Modules/TensorMechanics/Master]
  [all]
    strain = FINITE
    decomposition_method = EigenSolution
    add_variables = true
    use_automatic_differentiation = true
  []
[]

[Kernels]
    [inertia_x]
      type = InertialForce
      variable = disp_x
    []
    [inertia_y]
      type = InertialForce
      variable = disp_y
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [elastic_tensor]
    type = ADComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = 1e+4
    poissons_ratio = 0.4
  []
  [stress]
    type = ADComputeLinearElasticStress
  []
  [density]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'density'
    prop_values = '1'
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [hold_x]
    type = ADDirichletBC
    boundary = 'flexible_bottom'
    variable = disp_x
    value = 0
  []
  [hold_y]
    type = ADDirichletBC
    boundary = 'flexible_bottom'
    variable = disp_y
    value = 0
  []

  [Pressure]
    [push]
      function = 200
      boundary = 'flexible_left '
      use_automatic_differentiation = true
      use_displaced_mesh = true
    []
  []
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  end_time = 0.5
  dt = 1e-2
  solve_type = 'NEWTON'
  petsc_options = '-snes_converged_reason -ksp_converged_reason '
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_type -pc_factor_shift_type -pc_factor_shift_amount'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu       superlu_dist                  NONZERO 1e-15'

  line_search = 'none'
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-10
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-10

  [TimeIntegrator]
    type = NewmarkBeta
    beta = ${beta}
    gamma = ${gamma}
  []
[]

[Outputs]
  [exo]
    type = Exodus
    execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_END'
  []
  file_base = "ad"
  print_linear_residuals = false
[]

[Dampers]
[jac]
type = ElementJacobianDamper
[]
[]
What do the equilibrium shapes look like if you run a quasi static analysis?
Without the InterialForce Kernels.
So this implies a time integration error. Similar to your other post, try reducing the time step size.
So for this quasi-static problem, how would you get comparable results? Load-stepping the pressure term?

For steady problems and large deformation, does the new formulation require more attention? For 2 type = Steady (no time integration) problems (new vs old), I get the results below.
Blue is the old method, and white is the new method.

Also volume postprocessors data:
Old Method
Postprocessor Values:
+----------------+----------------+
| time           | volume         |
+----------------+----------------+
|   0.000000e+00 |   1.500000e-01 |
|   1.000000e+00 |   1.492346e-01 |
+----------------+----------------+

New Method
Postprocessor Values:
+----------------+----------------+
| time           | volume         |
+----------------+----------------+
|   0.000000e+00 |   1.500000e-01 |
|   1.000000e+00 |   1.334580e-01 |
+----------------+----------------+

This is seems like such a large difference for this quantity of interest for a steady problem.
Here is a comparison of new (green naghdi, black wireframe) vs old (red with white wireframe) with dt = 5e-4:
Would you recommend setting up time step recommendations (i.e. time step limits) based on the strain incrementation performed by the new system? Maybe as a material time step?

node.title: Error with Compiling
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSEers,
When I compile my application, the error always pop up, as shown in the screenshot, do u have any idea of what's the reason of it? Thanks.
Can you please attach the output of running the diagnostics script in moose/scripts

do you mean this one?
libmesh_diagnostic.log

When I cat/grep through your diagnostic log, I am not finding any hits for "20.02.5". I am not sure how that path is being made relevant during make of hound.
However, I am finding the following in the log relating to slurm:
/usr/bin/gcc -I/shared/apps/.gcc/8.3/openmpi/4.0.5/include -fexceptions -pthread -L/shared/apps/.gcc/8.3/hwloc/2.4.1/lib -L/opt/slurm/current/lib -Wl,-rpath -Wl,/shared/apps/.gcc/8.3/hwloc/2.4.1/lib -Wl,-rpath -Wl,/opt/slurm/current/lib -Wl,-rpath -Wl,/shared/apps/.gcc/8.3/openmpi/4.0.5/lib -Wl,--enable-new-dtags -L/shared/apps/.gcc/8.3/openmpi/4.0.5/lib -lmpi

Specifically:
-L/opt/slurm/current/lib
I think perhaps some part of MOOSE was built while on a different machine, where /opt/slurm/20.02.5 was available, but no longer. Did you perchance build some of the MOOSE dependencies/MOOSE itself while on a headnode for your cluster?
Thanks for reply. I cannot fully understand, I do build MOOSE in  the home folder on cluster, in parallel with other apps.

Something 'changed' from when you built PETSc, to when you built libMesh, to when you built MOOSE, to when you built hound. During one of those steps, /opt/slurm/20.02.5 was available... and then became unavailable.
Thanks. I cleaned the home folder and reinstalled MOOSE, but there was error after installed Petsc and do the check as below. what's the problem here

Does not look like a big "diff" to me.
Can you paste text under triple quotes instead of screen shots please
Does the rest of the installation work?

OK, I'll do copy-paste.
So it puzzles me, as I followed the protocol on the MOOSE website, but it does not proceed correctly, even at petsc stage. The rest also does not work.
BTW, the installation protocol is changing now and then, what's the reason for that?
We adapt the protocols as we find better ways to explain and more resilient installation methods, nothing wrong there

node.title: I want to make block rather than rectangular box.
node.bodyText:
Hello Moose experts.
I want to make a simulation block like the following.
1. Trapezoid.

Figure 1.
I wanted to make a trapezoidal block.
I tried StackGenerator and combined rectangular block and triangular block but it failed.
Here is the input file and the error message.
#####
xmax = 35
ymax = 20
#####

[Mesh]
  [./poly]
    type = PolyLineMeshGenerator
    points = '0.0 0.0 0.0
              ${xmax} 2.0 0.0
              ${xmax} 0.0 0.0'
    loop = true
#   num_edges_between_points = 20
  []
  [./tri]
    type = XYDelaunayGenerator
    boundary = 'poly'
    refine_boundary = false
    desired_area = 1
#    output = true
  []
  [./gen]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    nx = 35
    ny = 20
    nz = 0
    xmin = 0.00
    xmax = ${xmax}
    ymin = 0.00
    ymax = ${ymax}
    zmin = 0
    zmax = 0
    elem_type = QUAD4
  [../]
  [./stack]
    type = StackGenerator
    dim = 2
    inputs = 'gen tri'
  []
[]

===================================================================================
=   BAD TERMINATION OF ONE OF YOUR APPLICATION PROCESSES
=   RANK 0 PID 72460 RUNNING AT cnode14
=   KILLED BY SIGNAL: 11 (Segmentation fault)
===================================================================================

The reason why I didn't use only the PolyLineMeshGenerator and the XYDelaunayGenerator is that I believed I didn't want to make uneven and rough initial condition like Figure 2. An example of even and clean-cut initial condition is shown in Figure 3.


Figure 2. When I used only the PolyLineMeshGenerator and the XYDelaunayGenerator. Uneven and rough initial condition are made.

Figure 3. An example of even and clean-cut initial condition.
2. Boundary can be expressed as a simple function of x.
Also, I want to make a block of which boundary can be expressed as a function of x such as sine function or polynomial.

Figure 4.
Is there any way to make this? Can you tell me how?
Thank you so much for reading.

Hello
you are on the right track by making parsed curves.
You just want to not use the stack generator and use a stitchedmeshgenerator instead to merge the two blocks.
Also please note that you cannot have BOTH quad4 and tri elements in the same subdomain, they need to be in different subdomains (but they can be in the same mesh)
Guillaume
Thank you so much!

node.title: Heat extraction in a doublet
node.bodyText:
Dear community,
I am modeling a doublet in a monolayer reservoir only in TH.

My injection work perfectly however my extraction does not work. The temperature a the production well is heavily increasing over time instead of remaining constant and then cooling.
I have used all the available approaches in Point and line sources/sinks.

Injection in DirichletBC : imposing water pressure and temperature at the well imposing water pressure at the production well




Injection with [PorousFlowPointEnthalpySourceFromPostprocessor] and extraction with [PorousFlowPointSourceFromPostprocessor]




Injection with [PorousFlowPointSourceFromPostprocessor] and extraction with [PorousFlowPeacemanBorehole]



Injection with water pressure PorousFlowSquarePulsePointSource, temperature Dirichlet BC, extraction PorousFlowSquarePulsePointSource




Injection with [PorousFlowPointSourceFromPostprocessor]  and production with PorousFlowSquarePulsePointSource


Can you please help with that, in an ideal world I would like to inject with [PorousFlowPointEnthalpySourceFromPostprocessor and extract with PorousFlowSquarePulsePointSource.
Thank you
Here is my code
Aquifer_TH.txt
Mesh
mesh.txt

Hello
Disclaimer: not a subject matter expert
So the extraction is a point source (sink).
Is the mesh resolved enough near the extraction point?
@cpgr (a SME)
Guillaume

Thanks for the answer.
It is not mesh/node dependent. When refining and increasing the size of the refined zone, the extraction temperature still increases.

You need to make sure that you are producing both mass and heat, so need two production sources/wells - one for mass, one for heat. The PorousFlowSquarePulsePointSource doesn't have an option to easily do enthalpy (probably something I should add). You might be able to use the two 'source from post processor' point sources as sinks (just use a -ve mass flux).
I think the Paceman borehole approach should have worked though?

Perhaps like
[DirakKernels]
  [fluid_source]
    type = PorousFlowPointSourceFromPostprocessor
    variable = pwater
    mass_flux = mass_flux_in
    point = '5150 5000 500'
  []
